text: I heard a lot of good things about this place and they were all true. Cool ambience, nice staff & service. Food was delicious and presentation was exquisite. Good for vegetarians as well. Will definitely visit again when in the vicinity .

Great 4 course fine Indian cuisine lunch for $27 in a beautiful spacious and relaxed setting!  No reservations needed for lunch with plenty of room to host a large party. Service is attentive but cooking times are longer, so make this a lunch to linger and have conversation over.  The tandoori cooked Lamb and Chicken were the best, and the coconut dessert was perfect.

This was the worst dining experience I've had in over a decade of living in New York. First of all the waiter took 20 mins to take my drink order and bring me a menu. Waiting for my food took longer. I was dining alone and asked several times if someone was joining me. My meal was mediocre at best.  I debated saying something but it wasn't worth it as I just decided not to go again. After falling asleep I have now been up half the night with food poisoning. All in all an awful experience.

Tamarind is known to be one of the best Indian restaurants in nyc. I enjoyed everything we had ordered. I want to begin by saying the service is tamarind is remarkable. Our waitress was ready at our request. Any time we finished a drink she asked if we would like another. I did not like my mango cosmo- and when I told my waitress she quickly changed it to something else with a smile. We started with the malai chicken and the prawn special. We then got he chili crab, chicken tikka, and the lamb chops with the mushroom and truffle naan and garlic naan. Truly enjoyed everything about this restaurant. Highly recommended!!

I had high hopes given the review history. I had a group over 10 people  on a slow Tuesday night. When I got there they immediately pushed the prix fixe at 125 per head when they had multiple below and one above. I did not book this to be treated as another plate dinner. We went a a la carte which confused them. We had a few delicious apps but spotty orders on drinks. No idea what neat or single cube on what at 20 dollar drinks meant. Sorry I paid over 1500 eventually for 10 and felt like I could have gotten takeout went to a top notch cocktail bar and came out way ahead on food and drink without the cost. It was half empty and not worth it. I would pay gladly for glorious food and service but that was not it. Whatever glory they had is long goneStay away or you are just a sucker.

Our dinner here was very average as far as the food went. The restaurant was much larger than I expected and our server was super friendly. My cousin, my fiancée, and myself decided to order 5 entrees for sharing. We also had prawns and scallops to start. The scallops were by far the best thing we tried. Wonderfully cooked and a bit spicy. The shrimp were extremely overcooked and tough to enjoy.My lamb ghosht was mostly eggplant with two large pieces of stiff lamb. I can't really say I enjoyed this dish as it was hard to cut into. The sauce was decent. My fiancées halibut curry was pretty good but it could have used more sauce and been less cooked. My cousin's lobster masala looked intense and she also said it was super overcooked.Overall, we had a good time but there's definitely better Indian in NYC for a smaller price point.

Best. Indian restaurant. Period. * Everything is good. Seriously can't go wrong. Just know that if it says it's spicy - it is SPICY!  * Ambiance - clean cut style, comfortable, good lighting, Great ventilation and if you've been to Indian restaurants you'll appreciate that.

Used to be a great place when it was in The flatiron district. I used to take there, one of my kids all the time. Unfortunately the management decided to make it "kids not welcomed" in the restaurant. Terrible policy. What's next? No woman? Just remember you are in the restaurant industry, don't always believe your place is special, but care about your customers first.Just for this matter I invite you to pass  your way and choose another place.

A wonderful experience all around. Came here for my birthday it's a beautiful restaurant. The owner was very kind, and the waitress was attentive, funny, and warm. Everything we ordered was great! Some things that stood out include the crab appetizer. I never eat crab because I find that it can be fishy, but this was smooth and had a Smokey flavor almost. The scallops were also wonderful, and huge! For my main I got one of the shrimp dishes, which was served in a coconut with coconut sauce and mustard seeds. It was incredible, my brother agreed it was the best dish. Highly recommend this place if you want a nice dinner with different food.

One extra star for the ambiance. Besides that this restaurant really doesn't have anything going for it. The food is mediocre. Service was okay. Be careful with getting the pre-fix menu because they will service you one dish for all the people there. We ended up paying $1300 for 8 people which is so bazaar. So not worth it. They nickle and dime you for every little thing.If you're looking for a good experience in this price range, there are so many better alternatives such as Junoon and Rahi. However, if you JUST want an Indian restaurant with great ambiance and don't care about anything else, come here.

Came here on a Monday night for dinner. I was immediately impressed with the spacious interior, cleanliness, and friendliness and attentiveness of the staff. Service and everything was really great, but I just don't think the food was anything special, and I definitely think it's overpriced for what it is. None of the entrees come with rice or naan, you must purchase that separately. The portions are actually quite generous and I think an entree can easily be shared between two people! The garlic naan was also delicious. The best thing I had was a complimentary puff pastry type thing with cheese and peppers, it was divine! I tried two of the vegetarian entrees and they were just ok.

I have a feeling that Tamarind has seen better days. It used to have a Michelin star but hasn't for some years now, and this is evident in the quality of the food.Chicken tikka masala - We wanted to try Tamarind's well-regarded version of this classic dish. The sauce was better than many I've had. With rich, piquant flavors, it was spicier than many other versions. The chicken was a little tough, though, which was disappointing. Malai Halibut - Who wouldn't want to try the winner of the 2004 fish dish awards? I thought that sounded promising. The delicate sauce of ginger, coconut, mace, and cardamom was delightful, but the dish was very lightly sauced and it needed more because the flavors were so subtle to begin with. The fish also seemed a bit overcooked. Not quite worth the $38.We both agreed that we had eaten better Indian food in New York at a more reasonable cost. Try Seva in Astoria or a number of places in Curry Hill: Pippali, Tiffin Wallah, Spice Symphony.The garlic naan was savory and at once pillowy and crispy. 2.5 stars rounded up, because the sauces did taste good and the atmosphere was nice.

Favorite indian place to eat in the city. Great quality of the appetizers and the lunch items. Very hospitable and professional service. Detail oriented explanations of the kind of food you want to order. Should specify spice level to the waiters before ordering though because some curries might be on the less spicier side
The best place in New York City to have Indian. The food and service is always amazing. I love the tables off to the side with the curtains.

Elegant and delicious upscale Indian restaurant. Went for a family dinner. Service was very good. The lentils were special.Dessert was great. Everything really. It looks new and clean.Good pick by my gf.
Food used to be excellent but is no longer the case. But, the service is particularly subpar relative to expectations from a fine dining place.
most delicious indian restaurant ever. period. never disappoints. always impeccable service and always always the most incredible meals!

Beautiful decor. Service was on point. But I wasn't particularly wowed by the food. I'd give it a star more if it was a "mid level" restaurant but I believe it still has its Michelin Star and neither the creativity nor the taste really proved that. I had the ground nizami keens which was dry, to the point that you feel that it's stuck in your throat. My entree was the murgh lajawab. It tasted like any other regular chicken curry except to their credit, it was less creamy and heavy. I finished with a mango cheesecake and I just wish I hadn't. It wasn't airy. They likely used a lot of mango purée because there was a strong scent of mango but not so much of a natural flavor.

Amazing food and great service. Tamarind is one of the best Indian restaurant in nyc to represent upscale,find dining experience. Lobster masala is the star of the show. Lamb chops are delicious. Dover sole in the clay pot will fulfill the best possible dining experience you have ever had. Keep the good work going. All the best.

I went here for a friends birthday in early 2019. Hands down the best halibut curry I've ever had. The gosht curry was also amazing. A huge piece of goat meat served in a perfectly spiced sauce, goes great with some naan bread. The cocktails were also a delight.Definitely one of the best Indian restaurants in NYC.
cant fool an indian with fancy decortasteless bland foodfully uselessprice is for over staffed, shady decor amd furniture

Delicious! Introduced by a friend who is Indian-Australian and eats here regularly. The service is a little snooty and not super friendly, but the food is outstanding (albeit on the expensive side). And I highly recommend the Shami Kabab appetizer--not something I would normally try but now on my must-order-every-time list.

We tried it out during restuarant week. There is nothing to complain for a $26 three-course lunch. The food was decent with great tastes. It gave me a new impression on Indian food. The service is good.

I went here for the Restaurant Week lunch special with my husband and overall was a great experience. I found the food to be good but not amazing. It's a 3 course meal: Appetizer, Main (which comes as a single plate of 2 entrees, tomato rice, naan, and the vegetable curry of the day), Dessert. Cheese pakora with chutney: this was a free starter which I personally didn't have because I'm allergic to chickpeas (which they knew ahead of time and accidentally served it to me anyways and didn't apologize about it ). My husband had both pieces and he said it was amazing.Tropical Salad: this was a super light and fresh salad with mangoes. Great way to start the meal.Tandoori Broccoli: you get one large piece of broccoli layered on top of a red gravy. Both elements had great flavor and was well seasoned. you can definitely tell this was a tandoori dish. Kadai Paneer: I LOVE paneer to the point where it's not an official Indian meal without it for me. I was really excited about it but I found it to be lacking salt and had tons of large pieces of ginger that I would bite into. It was ok but definitely have had better versions of this dish at other restaurants) Potato Squash Curry was the vegetable curry of the day: this was a disappointment. It's clearly made in large quantities in the beginning of the day and served with everyone's meal so it definitely lacked attention. It was under-seasoned, lacked salt, and the potatoes had no flavor whatsoever because the pieces were so big that none of the curry spices actually got into it. Tomato Rice: great accompaniment Naan: super fresh and authentic. Probably my favorite part because it's hard to do a good naan without burning it.Gulkand Cheese Cake: the dessert was just the right portion. It was creamy and indulgent. I'm personally just not a fan of rose essence in food but I could appreciate that it was a well-made dessert.Service: our waitress was great and attentive. Only complaint is that they called us ahead of timeto check on allergies (chickpea) and told them again once we were seated and they still served me the starter which was coated in chickpea flour :/

My two friends and I went there for my birthday dinner. The ambiance was magnificent and the service was spectacular. We were greeted immediately and taken to our table. Our waitress was friendly and informative. We got two bottles of wine throughout the night. Our waitress told us the special. She was on point with telling exactly what the dish contains. We ended up choosing the prawns. We also got raj kachori. Wafer filled with chickpeas yogurt and tamirand and mint chutney. We also got samosas to start. All three appetizers were delicious. My favorite was the prawns. I ordered the lamb curry with mint Lacha parantha. The bread reminded me of the taste i use to have in India. It was absolutely delicious. The curry was spicy but not too much. The flavors were all in there mixed with the tender lamb. For desert, I ordered gajar halwa with ice cream. It was my favorite because it was not too sweet!  Throughout our dinner the servers were on top of filling the water when it was empty.  Picking up crumbs from the table as well. All in all a great experience. It is a bit on the pricy side, but worth it for a special event. Will be coming back.

This is probably going to be my favorite place for Indian food. Loved everything about this place : the ambience , the excellent hospitality, and the par delicious food! It's great for a fine dining experience , the place is gorgeous (silver cutleries, fancy lights ) , but most importantly amazing food. I tried this place during  the restaurant week , ordered a pre-fixed executive lunch having an appetizer, two entrees and a dessert . Portion size was good enough, being a vegetarian I had decent options to pick from. Ordered a kadhai paneer, tandoori broccoli with gulkand cheesecake.Five stars from my side! Must visit!!!

Our experience at Tamarind was really nice, but more because of the ambiance and the service and less because of the food itself. While everything was prepared well, the dishes did not manage to blow me away. Between the two of us we got-Shredded Kekda(crab) appetizer- slightly ketchup-y and tangy, the crab was cooked well. The dish overall was a 2.5/5Tandoori chicken breast stuffed with spinach and cheese appetizer- chicken had a really good flavor, so did the filling. 3.5/5Kadai Paneer and Tandoori Broccoli as vegetarian mains- both were flavored really well, especially the brocolli. Kadai Paneer- 3/5, Broccoli dish- 4/5Chicken and Lamb cured in spices as non vegetarian mains- both these meats were just above average. Nothing to write home about. Chicken- 2.5/5, lamb- 2.5/5We ordered the Kalonji Nan with our mains which was a delight and truly the main event of our afternoon.Not sure if we ll be back since there are many new Indian restaurants opening up that are pushing the envelope way further than the older more classic Indian restaurants in Manhattan.

I visited this restaurant for restaurant week. We were greeted with a very warm welcome by the staff and seated at a table with pretty settings. Everything went down hill from there. The staff that served my table seemed aloof and didn't even introduce themselves to us or ask us about dietary restrictions/allergies. The dishes of the day were not described, simply named. They moved plates around without telling us what was happening, presented food without describing what it was. We could tell the plates were supposed to be plated in a visually pleasing way, but many were coming out of the kitchen quite messy. I had the Halwa dessert which is supposed to be elevated by an apricot cream that it was served with. My apricot drizzle was actually solidified on to my plate so I could not even try it. The appetizer of the mango salad was overly sweet and missing an acidic balance. The food was otherwise tasty, but nothing special beyond normal North Indian cuisine. As a final kicker, we learned that asking for normal water was bottled Voss imported from Norway rather than tap water that every other restaurant I've ever been to defaults to. Would not recommend this restaurant to anyone.
Delicious food with the perfect spices. All of the staff members were so genuinely sweet.

This is a beautiful upscale restaurant. The service was excellent and people were extremely friendly. I think the owner came up to us and said hello. We got the lunch prefix menu for restaurant week. We got a little bit of everything to try which included the tandoori chicken appetizer and the crab cake. For our entrees we were able to choose 2 dishes, I got the lamb and the fish. The entrees came with a spinach dish, rice, and naan. Honestly, everything was lovely. The dishes were on the small side but there was a little bit of everything to try. For the dessert I got the cheesecake and my friend got apricot dessert which was also delicious and probably my favorite of the two. Also, I suggest getting the masala tea. I would definitely make my way to this restaurant again.

I have been a paying customer of Tamarind since discovering its original location near Madison Park and now the Tribeca home.  Tamarind is in my own opinion (as a British fan of Indian cuisine) one of the best restaurants for Indian cuisine in New York City and stands out from the pack at 'Curry Hill' near midtown.To address the "why ?" Question, as a paying guest I find the following differentiates Tamarind;- The restaurant is scrupulously clean and modern in design.  tasteful and not overbearing.- The service is good.  The owner, with a lifetime of experience in restaurants in the City knows how to train staff and set the expectations.- The food and drink is extremely consistent and whilst the menu adapts the quality is ever present.Favorites include the Tamarind Magherita, The Chilli Crab starter (spicy) and Chicken Vindaloo.  In fact, I can feel my taste buds now as I am writing this brief review.  I feel a little guilty having been so many times and not having sat down to write a review.Probably my only grouse is that Tamarind's only location is down town...

Came today for the start of restaurant week.  The place is beautiful.  We were seated in a both that was a little enclosed so it was nice because we felt we could talk away from the crowd.  Service is great.  Honestly it made the difference between 3 and 4 stars.  I'd say food is 3 but service and decor bump it up to 4.  Our server was Vinny.  He was super nice and attentive.  I believe it was the owner that stopped by and checked on us as well.  Seemed like he was super attentive and cared about customer service.  Now onto the food.  I started with the soup of the day which was a tomato based soup.  The flavor was good but it was too spicy for me.  I have to say the spice level was my biggest issue today.  I'm a mild spice kinda girl.  I should have asked so it may be on me but I'd say the spice level was more a medium on everything I ate.  For main course I had paneer and broccoli.  It was good but again too spicy for me to really enjoy fully.  Dessert I didn't like it was some apricot helva I think it was called.  Super weird texture and taste didn't make up for it.  I'm not sure if I'd return but I think it's a nice place with great service and food is good for someone who likes spice.

This restaurant offers a refined level of service - in my NYC South Asian experience matched only by midtown's Amma. This includes the hosts, servers and the owner/manager, all of whom were gracious.We came for an executive lunch - $27.00 for two courses and a small sweet. I started with the nicely spiced lamb patties, which were the best thing I would be offered. My companions  plumped for the garlic shrimp - three to the plate, and the salad.The glass of Hugel Riesling was excellent and I was offered a taste before the decent pour.For a main course, I had the fish (Hyderbadi Machli) and the Nizami Gosht (stewed lamb). The former was a good size portion of fresh salmon, but the lamb portion was on the small side and I did not think of it as any better than a buffet lamb korma or rogan josh. The herbed nan was excellent. I believe the vegetable was a stewed squash - quite tasty.Dessert - the semolina halwa, comprised a small wheat cake, which I enjoyed but my companions eschewed.I finished with a masala chai - served up in a nice pewter teapot.I enjoyed the experience, but can't say the food was definitively better than that offered at a top notch buffet like Bukhara Grill. But if you enjoy good service, this is the place for you.
Food, service and ambiance of the restaurant is great. Only downside is that it's pretty pricey. Almost $30 for chicken tikki without rice or naan is pretty steep

Among the Very Best!Okay, according to Open Table, I dine out more than 99% of others living in the NYC Metro, so believe me when I say Tamarind is among the best restaurants in NYC. Located in Tribeca, it's also a nice non-touristy spot near several of NY's best bars (for before or after). If you are a tourist and have never been to Tribeca, you should... it's a lovely neighborhood with narrow brick streets offering a different perspective on Manhattan.This was the second time in the past few years begun our New Year's Celebration with dinner at Tamarind. We started the night with a pair of Samosas, one with ground lamb meat, the other with chicken. Both were extremely tasty, of the two the lamb was off the charts. For my main dish, I had the Chicken Korma which was so delicious I can still taste it.  My mother-in-law had a spicy shrimp dish that she loved (and she is one picky diner with discriminating taste). My wife enjoyed a lamb dish which we all shared... also delish.The only question we asked ourselves the next morning was, why don't we dine at Tamarind more often, thus it's added to our list of New Year's Resolutions!
Great food ... amazing ambience . Great service and good options for vegetarians as well. Do not miss this place if you are in New York City .

We were just in for Christmas Eve dinner & it was absolutely amazing. The restaurant is beautiful & has a very lovely ambiance. When we were seated, the table was pulled out so we could comfortably sit. They also brought warm towels before & after the meal. Our plates & silverware were taken away after each course & we were provided with hot fresh plates. It's little things like this that take a good experience to a whole new level- much appreciated, thank you. The food was fantastic! All the full, delicious flavors of Indian food w/o the grease; I've never had such light Indian food. It is a bit pricey but definitely worth it. The plates were well proportioned & we all left stuffed. The only note I have is that our server spoke so softly that it was difficult to hear him at times. That being said, the service was also great, very attentive. Definitely a night of great fine dining & I do plan on returning. Thank you again!
Good fine dining Indian restaurant. If you want to try authentic North Indian cuisine- this is the place to go.Must try their Gajar ka Halwa and Daal Makahani.

Excellent Indian food. Excellent service. Trendy crowd. Really expensive for Indian cuisine. Would recommend only for special occasions, date night, etc. Expect a dinner for 2 with a cocktail each, 2 starters, 2 mains, and 1 dessert + tips to be $200. I personally would not come back again because I would rather try another restaurant for the same price.

Run to Tamarind in TriBeCa. It's run by good, kind, trusting people... and it's literally the most delicious Indian food on the planet! In my post workout blissful enthusiasm for Indian food tonight, I headed on my 20+ minute journey to Tamarind unaware that I'd forgotten my purse in the hotel. Upon arrival and realization of my error, the owner welcomed me with open arms and the offer to eat now and pay later. I feel like I've been proverbially kissed by a Christmas angel. Kindness and compassion - it's so comforting to know that it's alive and well. Thank you Wally, Geet, Adrian, and to entire team at Tamarind. Your restaurant is simply beautiful. Your food is delicious. But it's your team who made it special.

I think overall the quality of food was very average, there isn't anything special about the food and there isn't even an effort to present the food well. Quite disappointed to see a very well designed space ending up serving very average quality food. Not sure why it has been rated so well. You would be better trying other Indian restaurants in NYC, rahi being one of my favorites and can definitely give this a miss.

A beautiful restaurant with magnificent food. We were a larger group with a set price fixe dinner. We were all served a bit of everything and lots leftover on the table family style. Nothing was overly spicy but everything was incredibly flavourful and delicious. Each dish we had was unique and would definitely love to come again.
Great place! We only sat at the bar and had drinks and snacks but the food is excellent, the drinks are unique and delicious, and the service is great. Between that and the ambiance; I'll be back.

We had dinner here on a Saturday night. The restaurant itself is pretty, nicely decorated with tall ceilings and a second floor with seating. The service was good, but not great. Not anything egregious, but we had to wait over 15min and ask twice to get tea for dessert. We were also seated for 5-10min before being given menus.The food itself is similar, good but not great. The best dish we had was the spinach patty appetizer (hara bhara kabab). It had paneer inside and the sauce it came with was very flavorful. We also tried the raj kachori which was a crunchy wonton like exterior filled with chana masala. It was good, but nothing special. We thought it was weird that it was served cold.The entrees were the toplina paneer and nargisi kofta. The paneer was tasty, but each of the three different preparations tasted similar. The kofta tasted overwhelming of cardamom and was extremely rich. We ordered the spinach garlic rice and mushroom truffle naan to accompany the entrees. The naan was excellent, but I get annoyed by having to order rice separately.Overall the meal was enjoyable, but for the prices and experience, I would recommend baar baar instead. It would be more worthwhile for restaurant week.

I am a 10+ year customer of this restaurant and I can tell you it has really gone downhill over that period.  Today, I got food poisoning from eating the seafood here and vomited for fifteen minutes in the bathroom.  The management did not so much as offer me a refund.  Accordingly, I have contacted NYC 311 to report the incident and requested that American Express revoke their merchant account.  Avoid at all costs.

Prepared to be wowed by the service and the food. Impeccably presented. We had the executive lunch. Perfect amount of selections and perfectly prepared. We tried the Indian white wine I would stick with the Sancerre . Everything else was amazing.

Wow, so we went here last night for my sisters birthday. Best dinner ever! The food was so good! The appetizers were different but in a good way. The Chana chaat and crab cake were so delicious. Naans were nice a fluffy. The server gave us a variety of naans: garlic naan (best one), parantha thow naan (too greasy for me), and the broccoli cheese nAan ( prominent broccoli flavor). For entree we all got something different to try out. I got the Red pepper and yam soup... so good!!!! We got the Chana pindi, also a favorite and the Punjabi mutton omg to die for!!! Plus the goat is halal here, so we had too lol. The shrimp entrees were ok. We also go the seafood platter, ate the whole thing. The daal was ok, tasted too much like butter to me. The desserts tho. Omg each one we got was over the top in presentation and taste. The pistachio kulfi is a must!!! The gulag jamoon came with a mint ice cream, yummy. The Black Forest cake was their most popular since they had only 1 left. And the dark raspberry mouse cake was the perfect birthday cake. Service had to be on point here for the $$$$ point, and it was!!!! Best service . [one thing that bothered me was the server/owner whoever it was was bringing out more food or doubles or food items to fit for he table.... which did add up. Just a heads up] The bill yea... just make sure you have about a grand on the side for a dinner like this. So good, so expensive, and so tasty.
Tamarind is definitely go-to indian place in the city. The food is good and I'm in love with the ambiance. Its unfortunate that is a little too downtown to frequent more often. A must try!

Not just my favorite "Indian restaurant" in Manhattan, perhaps my favorite "restaurant", period. I love Tamarind. The service is always impeccable, the food is delicious and a solid value for what you get. It's an excellent place to take friends visiting the city. In summary, I go here more than I'd like to admit. The best thing on the menu is the lamb chops. The cauliflower appetizer is incredible (trust me). Also recommend the Lobster Masala with Naan bread (naturally).

I have been coming to tamarind for years and it's been one of favorites for great upscale Indian. I had my grad school lunch at the east side one way back in 2002. Went recently and was disappointed. Service was terrible. Told waiter multiple times that not to put cilantro in food. Apps came with cilantro and I reminded him again. I thought he would bring out new ones without but no. Entrees came out again with cilantro and this time he did prepare new ones but still. They forgot one of our dishes and I realized once we got home we were charged for it. Food was ok...it's gone downhill. There are better options.

We ordered and they told us 1 hour we waited 3 hours and every time we called they said the delivery guy was out.I got horrible food poisoning. The owner is a nasty human and I will never eat at this dump again.Thanks for nothing.

We have come here a lot over the years and have always liked it. The past few times we have gone we have really enjoyed the food even more so than before. The nuts at the bar, the paneer tikka and now the new Thali dish is amazing. Even dessert was good. Service is hit or miss depending on the waiter but overall - food like you get in posh hotels in India.

What a wonderful lunch at Tamarind! The space is modern, clean & beautiful and the service is very efficient & friendly. They offer an executive lunch menu as well as the regular dinner menu which is extensive and has something for every taste. The food was outstanding from the chicken to the lamb and the breads, each dish was perfectly seasoned and the meat was cooked perfectly. As an example, the Masaledar Chop, Lamb chops marinated in nutmeg, cinnamaon & Indian herbs was unbelievable-perfectly charred on the grill. For dessert, we both had the rice pudding. It was served warm with crushed pistachios and was one of the best we've ever had! Tamarind is the perfect restaurant for anyone who has not tried authentic Indian cuisine. We will definitely return!

I'm really sad because I truly wanted to enjoy this restaurant, but simply didn't. There are plenty of up and coming, trendy Indian restaurants opening up in the city and my family and I decided on this one because it had a more traditional menu. However, for the price point the food was at, I found their food to be below average. We're huge carnivores so to start we ordered their tandoori shrimp (jhinga e Aatish), lamb chops (masaledar chop) and chicken (murgh angarey half) to start. Also we ordered the fried cauliflower they had on their seasonal menu. Tandoori items were extremely charred and almost burnt which caused all flavor to be gone in the meat. We were really disappointed. We also ordered the fried cauliflower which we pleasantly did enjoy.For dinner, we ordered the lobster masala and dal makhni. Absolutely hated the lobster masala, had somewhat of a sweet makhni sauce which didn't pair well with the lobster at all. Also, the lobster was over cooked that caused it to have a tacky, extremely hard to chew bite to it. Hated this dish. Dal makhni was tasty.Being an Desi in NYC, I would say I have fairly high expectations when it comes to Indian food, as should be. This place did not deliver at all and was a complete waste of money. Sadly will not be returning. Much better options in NYC for Indian food!

My friends and I celebrated my 29th birthday here last night. The ambience and decor is beautiful and classy. I personally loved the mellow yellow lighting very much. It wasn't dark which I liked a lot since it makes it so much easier to take photographs.Drinks were strong and well made, well worth the $15. This place is not cheap so don't go in looking for a bargain. Our server was extremely nice and very attentive. He took photos, charged phones, made recommendations, answered questions and waited patiently while we indecisively ordered off the menu. The real great part for me though was the food. I'm half Indian and half Pakistani, and this city is full of mediocre desi food. I didn't go in to this place expecting a lot but I was simply wowed. First of all the menu is written so well in beautiful proper urdu. Reading through it is like taking a trip back home, and they feature dishes from all over the Indian subcontinent. The appetizers were sublime - the shaami kabab were beautifully made, so was the spicy crab, and malai chicken. The curries were phenomenal. I ordered the Kashmiri gosht and it was absolutely divine. The sauce was decadent and the lamb pieces were so beautifully tender. Other people in my party ordered grilled items. I especially loved the lamb chops and the milagu curry. Bread was made fresh and was delicious. If you want an authentic Indian experience in the city at a place where the chef knows what he is doing, look no further!

I was visiting my nephew in NYC. We had eaten here 4 years ago and I asked if he would be willing to go again. Much to my surprise (we did not grow up eating Indian foods or spices) he remembered and was elevated at the invitation!! We were lucky enough to be seated in Vinay's section which I will request next time! Viney made recommendations that were superb and challenged me to try things that I had net tried before. From now on, Tamarind will be a standard part of our NYC itineraries!!

We went her for dinner with a reservation. The food is good and delicious but definitely a little overpriced.  Paneer lababdar and paneer platter were the best we have ever had. Food will not disappoint you. But the service might. While we had reservations and there were number of empty tables. We felt like we were getting rushed. While we were still working on our food and drinks servers and waiters kept walking upto us asking us if we are done. 5 different times they walked upto us and the last time was really rudely. Instead of accepting the fact that they could train their people well, when we complained to the manager the response we got was you can cut it off from waiter's tip. That was not a good response. At the end of it, they did try making up for this. However, I was still not impressed with their service.

The owner is a jerk - my niece was at this restaurant recently and had an horrible experience ! Please boycott this place ! The Owner Walia seems to be the most culpable in this incident and should be taken to task for not being fair and not even bothering to listen to both sides of the story! Shame on you Walia !!!!

This is my first review ever on yelp. Tamarind has been a restaurant that has been a favoured spot but the last experience has scarred me for life. I know I will never go back. I was having a very pleasant dinner with my husband and a close friend. We had finished our meal and were ready to pay the cheque when a man on the table next to us interrupted us out of the blue, complained about how loud we were in the rudest way possible and claimed we were on cocaine. I was shocked; initially I thought it was a joke but soon it was apparent that it was anything but. The guy went back as though he did nothing and disrupted our evening significantly. For context, the restaurant was loud, it was a Friday night with multiple large groups dining and we were just three of us. Management swooped in to ensure we did not make a scene without making any effort to talk to the other party. When my husband went to ask for an explanation, the guy threatened punch him and when I tried to engage, I was called a wh**re. It's difficult at this point to not conclude - Racism - ironically, the owner, Mr. Walia was keen to land the blame squarely on us much to our dismay. Half an hour later, with the police involved, we did not make any progress. Apparently no crime had been committed. We got no apology and the owner of the restaurant was disgruntled with us! We also paid the cheque and paid the wait staff as they were not involved in the incident Overall, it was a downright infuriating and humiliating experience. In my ten years outside India, I have never felt this discriminated against. I can only speak to my experience, but I hope people read and make an informed decision before going to Tamarind.

This is my first review on Yelp .... I used to love tamarind before this. I have come here multiple times and had a good time.I went here today for dinner with my wife and a friend. We were almost done with our meal when a guy from the next table comes over and starts shouting at us. He told us that we were very loud and told me to shut the eff up. He also called my wife a wh**e and accused us of being on cocaine. We were obviously taken back and retaliated verbally. The girls called the wait staff for assistance while the guy was telling me that he would punch me in the face. I lost it at that point and told him to shut the eff up and sit down. The owner, Mr walia comes and reprimands me. He tells me that I shouldn't escalate things and I should just take it like a gentleman. Racists. The guy shouting was white and I'm Indian. He just took the white person's side and accused me of making a joke out of a fine dining room. The police arrived as my wife and my friend were scared as he threatened us verbally with physical abuse. Mr walia decided to give us a free drink after we paid $180 entirely for our food. He told me to forget about this as he was providing us with some wine.We still ended up tipping the wait staff as they are awesome drank our free wine as we deserved it and will never step back into this establishment again! I work nearby and a lot of our corporate lunches and dinners happen here and we will never come back.I hope anyone reading this review will understand how sympathetic this management is to racist people and stay away.

I had been to Tamarind's original Flatiron location years ago, thinking that it had been above average, but not the best Indian food I had experienced.  However, I had never been to the sprawling and elegant Tribeca version, but had heard very positive things and decided to give it a shot.  Upon our arrival, we made a pit stop at the bar, when my companion ordered some kind of cocktail that was the brick red color of Robitussin and did not taste much better than the dreaded cough syrup.  We were escorted to our table in the corner of the second floor balcony, providing us with an expansive view of the space.  We decided to start our meal with Vegetable Samosas, which were heavily fried and stuffed with potatoes and green peas.  The crispy dumplings were fine, but the dough was a bit chewy and made me think that they had previously been frozen.  The filling was also pretty mild and bland.  Thankfully, the meal improved from there with our robust entrees.  My Tenakay Murgh included large chunks of boneless chicken breast that were lean and tender.  The meat had been marinated with roasted coconut, madras spices, and ginger for a sweet and zesty flavoring.  The Lamb Vindaloo included succulent meat in a thick and spicy sauce.  Both meat dishes were so impactful that it was nice to have a side of Steamed Basmati Rice and some bread to help sop up every drop of sauce, though we had to order each of these on top of our meal - not even the rice was included.  When it came to Naan, we splurged and ordered three varieties.  The poultry in the Chicken Tikka one was rather dry, but the tangy Garlic and sweet Dried Fruit and Nut versions were phenomenal.Overall, Tamarind provided a classy and upscale Indian experience, but the food could have been better executed, given the higher price point.  I would give it a 3.5-star rating.

I came here with an 8:30 pm reservation on a triple date, and they were friendly enough to seat us 10 minutes before our reservation. While everything on the menu is absolutely delicious, the lamb dishes, naan, and desserts are unmatched. We ordered the Bataki Kosha (duck pastry), Samosas, and Dahl Aloo Poori (chutneys) for appetizers. For entrees, we got the Malai Halibut, Murgh Kolhapuri Chicken, Kashmiri Gosht, Steamed Basmati Rice, Pudina Paratha, Truffle Naan, and Rosemary Naan. For dessert, we bought the dessert sampler and herbal chai (the Gulab Jamun being my favorite dish from the Sampler). Finally, we all bought the lychee martini.Everything was prepared to near-perfection, with the exception of the chicken which was not as spicy as we had hoped. However, the chicken was still delicious and savory. In addition, the lamb was tender and flavored beautifully, while some of the chutneys tasted as if they were imported from restaurants in Delhi or Dhaka.I would pin the Kashmiri Gosht, Truffle Nan, Duck Pastry Appetizer, Gulab Jamun dessert, and the Lychee Martini as must-haves for dinner. Everything else was delicious, but could be substituted with other dishes from the menu. In addition, the service was great as our waiter was attentive and helpful. However, he seemed a bit too eager to push dishes onto our table. The ambiance is noisy and bustling, but the restaurant is gorgeously decorated. It feels like many high-end restaurants in India. Overall, I would highly recommend Tamarind to anyone who likes Indian cuisine!

The whole restaurant was empty but the hostess as soon as we entered was not really happy about the fact v had kids with us.. The hostess was taking us to our table then the other older gentleman came up and said we don't allow kids. If it was mentioned before I wud have been fine but the way it was told it was demeaning and really rude.. I have had food here it's not that amazing to be honest.

Good, solid Indian food in an upscale setting. The dishes weren't as delicately prepared as I expected, but they had a good combination of spices to form a nice tasty meal. Service was OK, but felt very rushed on a Saturday evening. We had a full dinner with dessert, and were "rushed out" after an hour and 15 minutes. The busboys kept coming by to remove our plates, even when there was food on the plate and fork in hand. I think they rely on turning tables as quickly as possible. It's difficult to savor a delightful meal when the entree is delivered while the appetizer plate is being removed.

I had ordered Paneer Lababdar. The waiter mentioned it is similar to Paneer Tika Masala. But, in actual, Paneer Lababdar was very bland in taste. It didn't have taste of the spice nor any salt. I think the Tamarind hotel is good inside but the taste is not very authentic Indian one. The price is also very high ...So visit at your risk to eat bland and pricy food

After a disastrous experience at Junoon the day before, my family made an emergency reservation at Tamarind to restore our faith in upscale Indian in New York. Tamarind is a reliable place to get good Indian food, period. It may not be one of my favorite restaurants, but when in need of a nice curry in a nice environment, Tamarind fits the bill. The Good: - Overall great food. All the curries we had were quite tasty; robust in flavor, spice and temperature (I now have nightmares of cold curry after my Indian experience the night before....). Some of my favorite chana masala in the city... yum!- Service has always been excellent. The first time we visited we had a wonderful waitress who was so knowledgable and friendly. This time was no exception, with an equally as cheery and helpful waiter. The Bad:- The ambiance is nice, but could use a "freshening up." A bit pre-2008 fancy, if you catch my drift. It also feels far too big. Love sitting downstairs in the booths, but sadly this visit had to sit upstairs which wasn't as great. - The water server was laughably rude. It's ok, other servers made up for it. Overall, I wouldn't regularly visit Tamarind, but I think in comparison with other similarly priced options in the city for Indian food, it's really good. It does have fierce competition from Indian Accent, but to me they're different enough to be considered separately from one another; if you want a solid curry with classic Indian flavors in a nice environment, this is the place. Food: 8/10Service: 8.5/10 (-.5 for the water guy...)Ambiance: 6/10Overall: 7.6/10

This was my 3rd visit to Tamarind. I love the ambience and food at this place but the service is a tad shoddy for a Michelin Star restaurant.I like the Vegetable Jalfrezi at this restaurant. It's the only place where I have had this authentic dish outside of India. Their kebabs are very good as well but stay away from the Hara Bhara Kebab which is not the best. Stay away from the Nargisi Kofta as well, nothing special.Overall a good experience but not the best, might not come back here for a while.

Loved the food. But found the environment almost too formal for my taste. The restaurant is very large, with two levels. We were seated on second story, all parts almost empty. It can feel strange to be in a large second floor area with only two other patrons. A few more diners did come.The restaurant still seemed less than half filled when we were done.The restaurant is chic and lovely in terms of decor. Staff formal. Food is presented to show off each dish.Cauliflower appetizer special was special beyond good. Prawns were amazing. We had a couple of lamb curries, and vegetarian one. Chicken tandoori special was beautiful, but a little dry. The rest of us wanted curries. The curries were good but were not exceptional from curries we have enjoyed elsewhere in NJ and NYC. They were tasty though expensive. Excellent naan and unusual rice options which were very good.We saw bartender making pretty cocktails. One in our party had a ginger martini. We had wine from an extensive wine list.We used to spend some time in London and this did remind us of an Indian restaurant we frequented there. It was inexpensive. This is definitely expensive. Food is delicious.

My absolute favorite restaurant. The room, the service, the food all are outstanding. Consistently combining flavors and textures creating UNBELIEVABLE food. I go for lunch, when a 4 course prix fixe lunch is less than $30 and everything is yum.

CRAZY good Indian food. It's fancy, so expect something a little different than your average Indian spot in Curry Hill.My sister and I came here on a Friday evening and ordered saag paneer and the meat variety -- I can't actually remember what the name of this plate was but it was a plate full of meats made in their oven. The spices and flavors were out-of-control good. The lamb fell right off the bone.We ordered ginger ice cream for dessert and also got the flourless cake. The cake was mediocre, while the ice cream was anything but. I'd definitely come back here for a special occasion or just for a nice night out.

Oooh I like Tamarind.I went to Tamarind with a good friend as a walk in on a Friday night.  We split a bunch of items, including:AMUSE BOUCHE: Stuffed bread with some sort of dipping sauce that I hoped to never run out of. SCALLOPS APPETIZER: Wow, OK.  I've never had scallops at an Indian restaurant before and that all changes NOW.  Spicy (by my standards) pan seared scallops in a sauce with fresh veggies chopped on top.  It was spicier than I personally thought it would be, but I was very pleased with this.DRINKS: Not so pleased with this; I got a very, very sweet margarita-like drink.  Definitely could have passed here / should've stuck to wine.HALIBUT: Saw on the menu that this was the "Grand Prize Winner of the 2004 USA Fish Dish Awards".  Quite frankly, I have no idea what that means, but I think the USA Fish Dish Awards people have the right idea here.  Halibut in a ginger + coconut sauce served with asparagus.  Pre-portioned out.  CHICKEN TIKKA MASALA: It's not 100% fair because I've never met a chicken tikka masala that I didn't like, but this one was very multi-dimensional and had several enjoyable layers of spice.  At $27, this is one of the pricier Chicken Tikka Masalas I've ordered, but certainly enjoyed this.Also ordered some naan and a decaf coffee at the end - both fine.All in all, I would certainly go back to Tamarind.  The one thing that I would warn is that those with more sensitive-to-spice palates should be careful here.  While what we ordered was by no means outrageously spicy, everything had a 'kick' to it.  Delightful for me, though!
Vinay gave us great customer sevice tonight! He recommended several dishes we loved. Drinks, service and food were all perfection. Wonderful atmosphere for date night.

The two words that best describe this place would be 'over priced'.  Channa Saag was okay, better than many, but $23?  Please!  Nan was absolutely nothing special at over $5.  Bill was nearly twice what it should've been.

Tamarind is a great, fancy, Indian restaurant. I came here for my mom's 60th birthday with my family and we were going because it is a "special occasion" restaurant. Though they didn't really treat us that "special" given the occasion, only gave us a candle in dessert.Food highlights:-dahi aloo poori: everything you want from an Indian chaat -- sweet, salty. crispy-Nawabi shammi kabab: delicious lamb patties! -Raunak e seekh kabab: phenomenal lamb chops with a delicious sweet and sour plum sauce-Flourless Chocolate cake for dessert was a great way to finish the meal

If you're looking for a fancy Indian restaurant that had both great food and service, look no further! We came here late on a Saturday night, right before the kitchen was about to close. The restaurant was almost empty and we were able to get a booth.They start out with warm towels, which were very refreshing for us, given we had been walking all over Manhattan for hours before this.For appetizers, we got the jumbo prawns. I'm a vegetarian but other people liked it a lot.For the main course, we got a paneer lababdar and a chicken lajawab, both very good. The naan was fresh and very soft. We didn't get dessert this time but I'm looking forward to going there again!

We tried to make a reservation here for a group of 18 people. They let us know that the rule made by the owner is that a group of 9 or more has to spend $75 per person. We obviously would most likely be spending more than that with drinks, appetizers, entrees and desserts. The thing is, is that for any reason if you spend less than that they will still charge you $75 per person which is ridiculous. We will be taking our group somewhere else for dinner

I visited Tamarind with my dining group for Restaurant Week and we loved the experience.  For the appetizers, we had the crab (must try) and lamb skewer (alright).  For the entrees, we had the fish (must try), lamb (delicious), chicken (delicious), and paneer (alright).  I also want to recognize our server Vinay.  He had a good sense of humor and it enhanced our experience with the fantastic foods.
One of the best Indian restaurants in NYC area. I have been there during restaurant week and was surprised by the hospitality and quality of food.

1 star: Sitting at the bar right now waiting for my party to arrive. Decide not to get a drink because I'm starving and don't want alcohol on an empty stomach. 30 minutes go by and bar tender never offered me a glass of water.  Let's see where this goes. ------------Ok I'm back. Party finally arrived we get seated and presented with drink menu. Another 20 minutes go by with no one coming back to take a drink order. No menus yet. Got up to ask for menus. Drinks (two bottles of wine) arrive after another 20 minutes. Another 20 minutes go by and someone finally comes to get our food order. Are you counting? That's an hour after we sat down. We order and chat and wait. And wait. And wait. 40 minutes later our appetizers arrive. Then Another 30 minutes till our mains. Two hours into this dinner at this stage. Good thing the company I'm with are talented conversationalists. Now for the food: I go mixed grill asked for all chicken on the plate dark meat chicken but was told they portion the meat so not possible but the waiter assured me the white meat wouldn't be dry I think great. Guess what...it was dry and overcooked. For the prices they charge his is pretty unforgivable. I'm bored with this review now and can't be f'd telling you about the other underwhelming dishes other people got. Adding 1 more star because our waiter had a very professional manner about him and also offered the birthday girl a little something sweet.Our bill came to over $800.Go to Badshah on ninth ave. Do yourself a favor.

I honestly felt a little out of place upon entering Tamarind; it has an extremely high end feel. However, our waiter immediately made us feel at ease. The aloo tikkiyas were the highlight of the meal! They're the perfect blend of sweet and spicy. We ordered chana pindi and kalaikkose pirattal for our entrees and loved both (although the chana pindi was slightly spicier than I anticipated).

Went for RW lunch. Big amount of food for $26 but taste was a little disappointing. The appetizer - lamb skewers a bit overcooked and crab meat very plain flavor. Entree I got lamb and bitter gourd - sauces were good very spicy. Lamb was not as good as the skewers. Rice was good with very interesting spices. I did love the nang but they were quite little pieces and there was a charge if you want more. Desserts were disappointing... we got custard and fruit ice cream. Super sweet but lacked thickness. Also taste quite artificial. I would have given three stars but I lower a star down because my stomach was burning for the whole afternoon and night after the lunch. I am not sure if there is any ingredient or spice that I am allergic to or something is wrong. This fine dining Indian spot basically did not impress me at all and I don't see it better than normal Indian restaurant.

Tamarind is a special place. Its considered high End Indian cuisine and they live up to this. The place 1st of all is gorgeous.  The bar upon entering the place is on the left. The staff are quiet and focused on achieving a serene dining experience.  The space between the seating is enough to carry a discreet conversation without anyone listening in. The place was almost empty when i arrived at 6pm. When i left, the was not an empty seat in the house. If you like or love Indian cuisine,  and being in lower Manhattan and price is no object, Tamarind is great place to dine. The menu and the diversity of flavors plus a nice list of wine, including undervalued Australian wines, just proves what you can achieve with attention to detail.  Hiren (hope i spelled his name right), was our server and he knows how to direct and please his customers. He has such a smooth demeanor and it would be a pleasure to have him as a server again. He does good for the restaurant,  in fact he asked to return soon to try more items on the menu.  He asked very nicely and very smoothly. I will certainly consider. I most certainly will refer some people to done here for sure! We ordered a bottle of Two Hands, Sexy beasts from South Australia.  Wow, what a smooth drinker. So many Australian wines most people neglect. Look into it.  We had garlic naan, spicy crab (quite nice), Murgh Malai Kabab (grilled chicken in a superb marinate), Tenakay Murgh and Lobster Masala and finally ended with Gulab Jamun (milk pastries in honey). We were quite satisfied woth everything!

I loved Tamarind. The food here is very authentic. Their Thikhe Kebab and their lamb kebabs. Their vegetarian platter was also excellent. The good news is that Tamarind is Indian food as you would expect it with authentically Indian flavors and spice levels. Everything here is exactly as one would have expected at a high end restaurant in India and it showcases great Indian food.  The restaurant has a great ambiance and great service. My only quibble is that it's a trifle overpriced for the food.

$89 for Indian food?! Only two dinners, appetizer, and naan! $23 for some vegetables in a lame sauce. The eggplant dish was ridiculous as well. How much money are these people making on us?! I expected this place to blow me away for the prices but alas it did not. Oh and the naan wasn't so great either. The service was great, and the decor pretty cool, but unless you have money to burn, go spend 1/3 of the price at another place that has much better food. Sorry.
Came for restaurant week. The variety and quality was outstanding. The service was friendly, helpful and attentive from Vijay and staff. Never had to ask for water or anything.

Best: Naan, Tutti Frutti.Good: Tamarind Mousse, Afghani Murgh, Shahi Paneer, Crab Nazakat, Coco Malai Halibut.Skip:Rajasthani Sooley,Zafrani Boti.I don't know what they do, but this is the best naan I ever had, and I've been to very many Indian places. Both the lamb dishes, Rajasthani Sooley (Grilled lamb skewers, malt vinegar, olive oil, deggi mirch, mint coriander chutney) and Zafrani Boti (Tandoori lamb marinated in hung yogurt, nutmeg, saffron, spicy peach chutney) were not up to par. The meat was tough to chew.Good:--Tamarind Mousse (Tamarind infused custard). --Afghani Murgh (Chicken marinated in yogurt, roasted chickpea flour, crushed spices, almond bell pepper chutney). --Shahi Paneer (Cottage cheese in tomato, yogurt, fenugreek, garam masala). --Crab Nazakat (Lump crab meat, coconut, honey, lime zest, mustard seeds, curry leaves). --Coco Malai Halibut (Halibut simmered in coconut milk, lemon zest, fenugreek seeds, curry leaves). The Tutti Frutti (Ice cream with stone fruits, citrus and berries) had the most delicious ice cream. Too bad I was sharing and not at home, or I would have licked the plate clean.Our server, Vinay, was delightful and jovial. Even though this was a large space with many people, it was not too loud to have nice conversations.
Excellent upscale and trendy Indian restaurant. Menu was fantastic, great service ( our server Vinay was outstanding). Don't wait to try this place if you are in the mood for good Indian food.
Best Indian food I've ever eaten!  Good quality food, atmosphere and service.  The tandoori chicken and seafood dishes are particularly worth mentioning.

Simply put this place has good ambience with mediocre food. Over/under cooked depending on the dish, overloaded with masala/spices and prepared more with quantity in mind Vs quality. If you are an Indian origin person you can compare the food to your average mid-town buffet place with all-you-can-eat North Indian food for $11.95, except with a misplaced decimal point!If you are a visitor and are looking for a great experience with every meal then this is not the place to spend your evening. The ambience is great, service is just ok, but the food will let you down. Look for alternate options like Junoon on 24th street.

I rlly liked the chic and modern decor here. The food and service was pretty good too. The lamb skewers as appetizer is super flavorful; it was actually my favorite dish of everything I ate. I can't rlly handle spicy and told the server beforehand so he recommended the halibut and chicken as entrees. He was right! The halibut was good and not spicy at all, but I thought the chicken was too dry and a bit spicy.
The ambience was really great. It was a bit on the pricier side but definitely worth it. The food was delicious. Will visit again.

Although the staff are very polite and this place has a great atmosphere, I was a not a huge fan of their lunch special. I found the Halibut and the chicken dish to be somewhat bland and in need of a little more flavor. It took a while to get our dessert and our check. I can't speak for the other dishes which are not on the lunch menu. It seemed as though this place had a regular crowd, so it seems like a popular lunch spot for the locals.

Excellent service and excellent food - we were in New York for 3 days.  Tamarind was highly recommended by the Four Seasons Staff.  Out of the 3 days we ate dinner at Tamarind for 2 days - it was that good!  The lamb chops, lamb and chicken dishes are clean and authentic.  The service superb!  We were served by Vinay and he was exceptional in his advise as to what items to choose depending upon our likes and dislikes.The second day there was a bit of a wait as we requested for Vinay to be our server.  The bar tenders were just as knowledgeable on drinks and also provided excellent service.I would highly recommend Tamarind and make sure you get Vinay as the server.  I'm sure all are good but he has a consultative nature and a very good personality.Fine dining at it's best - as it should be - no complaints!!
I'm surprised they don't allow kids under 7 years old. This is the most kids unfriendly restaurant I ever seen.

I was there with family for one day NY trip. Food was ok. Service was great. Many server eager to help. Odered Rajis Thali.... was ok not great. Chicken tikka came 3 pieces only and Bhel was regular. Disappointed with dessert.... you can order for numbers of people... odered for 2 not good.

Upscale Indian tastes and menu with unique spins on drinks as well. This is near my office so I bring people here often and it does not disappoint. The menu changes up frequently. I have several times requested specific items be made from the menu and have always been accommodated.

Great Ambience OK Food!Perfect date place but food is just ok for its price. We had ordered murg kebab, nargisi kofte, pudina naan, garlic naan and creme brûlée. Also ordered monsoon drink. Most of the food was good except the entree Nargisi Kofte. It was pretty bland and had no flavor. Pudina naan also had too much pudina which was overpowering the naan. Ambience is great. Can get a little loud with big groups.

Romantic ambiance, great service and delicious food is how I would like to describe Tamarind. The best part about this place is that it brings out traditional Indian flavors out on the table. The presentation is top notch and the staff is polite and friendly. We ordered their signature cauliflower starter which was absolutely delicious. I was excited about the Murg Malai Kabab but it disappointed me - although the flavor was on point, the meat was not at all soft and succulent as it ought to be. For the main course, we ordered Paneer lababdaar, Dal Makhani and garlic naan. The Dal was absolutely lip smacking and the naan was super soft! For dessert, we went by their recommendation and ordered some ice cream. Loved that as well! I would recommend Tamarind to anyone who is looking for authentic Indian flavors in a beautiful and classy set up - perfect for a date or to celebrate a special event.

All my date had to say was "lobster and seabass" and I was in. This place has definitely changed the way I think about Indian food- it's upscale, delicious, and their food is always so flavorful! Tamarind Seafood Platter ($41)- 5/5 Lobster, shrimp, scallops, sea bass, seasonal fish with a side of tomato raita and rosemary nan. Do I need to say more? Everything was so well marinated, flavorful, and perfectly cooked! The platter is best for one hungry person since the portions aren't huge.

Overall Experience: One of best fine dining Indian cuisine places in New York / New Jersey, with very good service from the staff.Items ordered: Raji's Thali, Chicken Lajawab, Broccoli & Cheese Naan,  Chicken Tikka NaanAmbience: Peaceful, Fine dining restaurant ambience with nice lighting and light decor.Breadth of Items: Decent array of items spread across Vegetarian, Chicken, Mutton/Lamb, and Sea Food items with a nice flavorful profile across the items. They also  have a good collection of Indian Desserts.

One of the best restaurants I have been to in NYC in decades and certainly the best Indian food I have ever had.  Fantastic service.  Attention paid to quality and a high end dining experience down to the utensils, bowls and other serving items. Many thanks for an great dinner.

Son of a bitch, lamb curry. Son of a bitch, lamb curry. Son of a bitch, lamb curry. Son of a bitch, lamb curry. Son of a bitch, lamb curry. Got the lamb curry and it ruled. Also shared chicken tikka masala and an eggplant dish, plus veggie samosas and garlic naan. Great wine list. VERY attentive service.

Lovely trained service, and beautiful space.  Synchronized service. But, then there is the food. Very disappointed as we left with without remarks after eating. We arrived hopeful and left with a one and done conclusion.  Amma in midtown is better.  Using Rasika and Chutney Mary as the benchmarks, we were very disappointed in what Tamarind delivered. Left with a complete understanding on the disappearing Michelin star.

I've eaten at Tamarind a few times already. Every time, the service was impeccable and the food, reliably excellent. You can tell they make it fresh everyday; that it's not another frozen food affair (I would hope so; it has a Michelin start after all).Last weekend however, my brother and I threw a surprise party for our Mom. We started organizing a little late, but the manager at Tamarind rolled with the punches and provided us excellent support & service for a moment we will never forget. Their logistics were on point.I highly recommend Tamarind not just for lunch/dinner, but also for your events.

Not what it used to be. The food was still good, but the service was terrible. The servers were not at all attentive. For the type of "high class" restaurant it is supposed to be, the service at Tamarind was terribly disappointing. I had wonderful company to make up for it. But, I would now think twice about coming to Tamarind again.

The best of the best!   Food, atmosphere, service all beyond reproach.Even on Mother's Day with a party of 9, we were shown to a quiet tableand had a great Mother's Day family visit with exciting food choices for our dining pleasure, thoroughly enjoyed by one and all.  thank you, Tamarind
if you have a child below 7 don't even look at this restaurant. most ridiculous place who don't allow kids below 7. never heard of this before.
Consistently excellent food and service. Very professional and modern take on Indian cuisine. Great selection of unique cocktails as well. Will definitely return here.
Attractive restaurant with mediocre overpriced food and spotty service.Many better choices for Indian food. Not worth the inflated prices.

Went here for a team dinner on a weeknight. The food was absolutely amazing - hands down arguably one of the best Indian restaurants in the city. Would have given 5 stars if it did not take our waiter 1 hour to hand us a menu. Other than that, this is a place to go to if you're in a group and want great food with pretty much white glove service.

My husband and I were walking around the city today and ran into Tamarind. We took a look at the menu in the window and everything looked great.We started our meal with vegetable samosa and roasted pepper soup, both were full of flavor and spice! Simply delicious.For our main courses my husband had the Punjabi tikhe kabab and I had the paneer lababdar; both dishes were really great. The goat cheese with spinach was wonderful. I would highly recommend checking tamarind out! The service and ambiance is really amazing! Can't wait to come back and try other items on the menu! Thanks for a great experience!

Host did not seat me in desired area. The restaurant was empty at 6, we also had reservations with notes. She Said the second floor was for 4-6 tabletops. Sat in the back with no view of this gorgeous restaurant. Service was excellent, very attentive waiter. Food was very good as well.

Absolutely amazing food and service. Not only was the food authentically flavored and delicious, they had incredible service and were able to explain each dish to the table and those unfamiliar with Indian food. We opted for a prefix menu with many options and some catered to specific dietary restrictions. The one thing that surprised me was the amazing and decadent chocolate cake, a dessert I would go back for again and again.
Incredible food, incredible service. Pure bliss. Best samosas I've ever had. The lamb chops are divine and the halibut was a surprise favorite. Definitely worth a trip here!

The worst .. been going there for years .. I celebrated every occasion there.. this time I wanted to go there for daughter's first birthday .. but all of sudden they have a child policy.. when I took my kids before there.. very disappointed .. they said under 7 not allowed so does that mean I can't go there for another 6 years lol .. who will want go after that .. I mean if they don't my money 9 to 10 times a year then it's fine I will take my money somewhere else ...
This place is highly overrated. Food is expensive. Quality is mediocre and service is sub par.  There are much better Indian cuisine options in NYC with greater quality.

The food was incredible - great selection of authentic Indian food. Service was extremely polite and amazing. I would highly recommend this restaurant for a date night or special occasion. Cocktails were also very good.

So, this spot is not affiliated with the London restaurant, although each of these venues has been awarded one Michelin star. I came for dinner with 4 people. Our server seemed new-ish and thus he was not on the ball. In fact, the manager was picking up his slack. The manager was superb and very knowledgeable. The cocktails we had were a mixed bag, some were excellent (for example the cardamom martini... forget the name) while others were not too good. We ordered a mixture of vegetarian dishes and meat. I will call out the stand out dishes. Onion naan (versus others), Brussel sprouts, cauliflower (amazing), veg samosas. The lamb vindaloo was very good, along with the veg byriani and saag paneer. Overall the food was excellent, unique, and had a good mixture of traditional dishes and twists on indian cuisine. Worthy of it's star.
Good food and service.  Upscale Indian restaurant with great decor. Would definitely recommend this place if looking for good Indian food in a great atmosphere.

Top notch service and delicious food. I'm typically not a huge fan of Indian food but came here because of a recommendation from a coworker. Service was prompt and waitress was extremely attentive. Would definitely be back.

Overall is a good festive atmosphere with interesting variety on the menu. But a bit disappointed. Maybe my expectations were too high.  The place is vast and noisy. The service is ok as they try to attend to you (but we waited way too long to be served with the menu) and the food is good but not as good as I expected.

Came here with Ralph yesterday (think his mom really likes the restaurant), it was delicious!We got the jumbo prawns appetizer (three big prawns coming in a delicious tangy sauce), then he got the Malai Halibut fish for main course (a grand prize fish dish winner apparently ^^) and I got the Chicken Shahi Korma which was really nice. Tried the lemon rice which came with cashews and of course fresh naan bread. Service and waitress was great too! :)

Nizami Kheema and chicken angrey( tandoori chickin) are very authentic in taste.  Definitely will order again in my next visit, Chicken biryani is ok.. not worth of $27.  Chicken kolhapuri is just like any other chicken curry, not up to the mark.  Service is excellent and servers are very professional.

Coming to the point, the food was OKAY. Topli na paneer (paneer cooked three ways) was really good. Hara Bhara kabab was good too. But I ordered veg thali and my husband ordered some chicken gravy and both were average. Probably just a point up from journal square restaurants. For desserts, I ordered cardamom creme brûlée, it was good.Cocktails weren't great for the price. When you combine alcohol with indian flavors, they are suppose to complement each other but somehow they didn't. In short, I paid around 185$ (including tip) for 2 people and wasn't as satisfied as one would expect for this kind of price. Ambience and Service was decent.

Much larger than I expected, as the restaurant has multiple levels and a wide sprawling room. The appetizers were the best I've had from an Indian restaurant. The bataki kosha (duck in hand rolled crepes) and Tamarind scallops were both phenomenal. The main courses were good too, but didn't blow us away like the appetizers.
Our finest dining during our last trip to New York.  The halibut is a must!  Scallop appetizer was some of the best I've had.  And the Rice pudding was a fabulous was to end the meal.

It was quite a mixed experience! The teaser appetizer (free) was good; unfortunately the two appetizers we ordered were shabby. It appeared cooked hours ago and not even heated in a microwave. Same with entrees. Desert was good. I was quite disappointed. Neither will I go nor would I recommend. I dragged a business colleague there so was unfortunate, as he wanted to go to another Indian place.
It's a nice restaurant but the food is not tasty at all. Too expensive for the quality of food. You can have better taste in any other Indian restaurant.
The food was amazing and the service was top notch.  I was with a group of people and we ate family style.  The best part was the lamb chops.  They were so good.  I would recommend this restaurant.

Delicious food from a former Michelin star-holder! Tamarind May have lost their star in 2015, but it's still got some tasty options available in a classy environment. We had the kolambi pola to start, which is sautéed prawns in a delicious coconut curry served with a crispy chickpea patty. The shrimp was cooked well and the sauce was delicious!For entrees, we shared the topli na paneer (paneer tikka marinated 3 ways), murgh kolhapuri (spicy chicken in a tomato-based curry), and the tandoori salmon special. The paneer was soooo good! The chicken kolhapuri was cooked perfectly and was medium-spicy. Every now and then a whole peppercorn would be in the spoonful, so that gave it a kick. The real star of the meal was the tandoori salmon! If this is available when you visit, you should definitely get it. It's a roasty, moist cut of salmon, served over a bed of grilled peppers, onions, and cabbage and drizzled with tamarind and yogurt sauces. So. Good.Lemon rice and garlic naan were good, as were the cocktails and dessert. We had rasmalai, cardamom creme brûlée, and the coconut mousse bombe. The creme brûlée was our fave of the 3, but the rasmalai was a close second!Book on Open Table and you'll get bill updates as you order, then you can use Apple Pay at the end and never have to swipe a card! Convenient! The meal is pricey, but you're paying for the name, the ambience/locale, AND the delicious offerings. It's a good spot for a special occasion.

Our friends wanted to visit Tamarind because of the Michelin star. We'd never tried Indian food in a fine-dining setting before so we were really looking forward to this (so excited that we got there a whole hour before our reservation!)Pros:* Great Drinks - my Mango Cosmo was utterly delightful, flavorful yet potent! We also got a bottle of Indian wine for the table, that the wine-drinkers enjoyed. The mango lassi was also very good* Décor: Elegant, albeit slightly sterile.* Service: Friendly without being intrusive.* Lamb Chops: These were REALLY good - juicy, SO flavorful - really nicely doneCons:* Food: Other than the lamb, the rest of the food (5 vegetarian dishes and rice) was at most average - the kind that you'd get at your friendly neighborhood Indian take-out shop (for 1/4th the price). The worst was undoubtedly the sad, sad okra which seemed like it was simply sauteed with NO seasoning. The food was so 'meh' that none of us could muster up enthusiasm for dessert (and if you know me, that's saying a lot!)Overall, it was a decent experience, but nothing to write home about. Given the 3 dollar signs, a return visit would definitely not be worth it.

I've heard about this place few times! So like any Yelper, I decided to see what the hype is all about. Well, let me tell you...hype's real! I've now been there 3 times. Due to time constrictions, I don't get to stump the concrete jungle as much as I should. Great place for a date night, or if you're into that group thing! From the moment you walk in, you know you're going to enjoy your time while there. Staff is friendly and attentive without over bearing. Food is spectacular. Presentation is well executed. Wine list tops some of the finest restaurants. I'm a cork dork, so I act like a little kid at a toys r' us when I see a well put together wine list. Seriously if you love Indian food, I know I do, check this place out! That is if you haven't already. They also have signature cocktails! Which were bloody awesome! Though, I only tried two, but it was enough to convince yours truly! Btw- Make sure you make reservations, this spot gets filled dumb quick! Oh, and you do get to see some famous people in there every now and then given their location. Ok, I think I've said too much!
Great high-end Indian cuisine. It's been around for a while and has a nice ambiance. They do a nice drink selection and the staff is professional. The food was tasty and creative. Worth a try.

My boyfriend and I were really excited to try this place. It was his birthday, and he *loves* Indian food. We ordered drinks first. He got the spicy margarita (Tikhi?) which was good but too sweet for me, so I got some wine. We were treated to some complimentary pastries to start, and we agreed that the sauce was delicious. We ordered a daily special appetizer--lightly-battered cauliflower in some kind of sauce--that was amazing, and made us extra excited for our entrees. After a lot of hand-wringing over entrees (I didn't want to get anything too traditional), he got Murgh Kolhapuri and I got the Majjiga Pulusu. I took one bite of mine and knew I'd send it back. It was spicy, but that was its only flavor--otherwise, it was bland. He said his was underwhelming as well ("the only flavor is spice"), but he kept it. I got the Bhagarey Baigan for round 2, which was okay but not great. The garlic naan was good, but I can get garlic naan anywhere. We haven't been in the city long, and we were excited to eat at a place that was so highly-reviewed. We left wondering what all the fuss was about, especially given the bill. We're both handy in the kitchen, and he's made Indian dishes at home that we liked better (though granted, it's a time-consuming venture). It's possible that we just ordered the wrong things, but I don't think we'll be back. I have to say that the ambiance was very nice, and our server was friendly. They also brought up a small complimentary piece of dessert, since it was boyfriend's birthday, which was very nice.

Came for Restaurant Week in winter 2018 and had a great lunch experience.
